'''Enrique Gil Robles''' (1849–1908) was a [[Spain|Spanish]] law scholar and a [[Carlist]] theorist. In popular public discourse he is known mostly as father of [[José María Gil-Robles y Quiñones]]. In scholarly debate he is recognized principally as one of key ideologues of [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalism]]; some authors view him also as major representative of a theory of law known as [[Natural law|iusnaturalismo]].
==Family and youth== [[File:Gil y Carrasco.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|[[:es:Enrique Gil y Carrasco|Enrique Gil y Carrasco]]]] Enrique’s paternal ancestors were a family of modest [[Hidalgo (nobility)|hidalgos]] from [[León (historical region)|Leon]]. His grandfather, Juan Gil, settled in the town of [[Villafranca del Bierzo]], serving as administrator of real estates belonging to [[:es:Marquesado de Villafranca|Marqués de Villafranca]] and those owned by the local Catholic Church.<ref>Raquel Pérez Valle, ''Biografía. D. Enrique Gil y Carrasco'', part 1: ''Su nacimiento'', [in:] Ricardo Gullón (ed.), ''Cisne Sin Lago. Vida y obra de Enrique Gil y Carrasco'', Madrid 1951, p. 6, available [http://perso.wanadoo.es/jlpv/vida/index_nacimiento.htm here]</ref> Though a conservative, during [[Trienio Liberal]] (1821-1823) Gil was particularly active enlarging Villafranca’s holdings by massive purchases of former Church property, put on sale during the first wave of [[:es:Desamortización española|desamortización]]. Following the death of marqués, audit of his possessions performed by state officials revealed that there were 20,114 [[Spanish real|reales]] missing.<ref>Pérez Valle 1951, p. 6</ref> Though there were many doubts lingering, Gil left in disgrace and settled in [[Ponferrada]].<ref>Pérez Valle 1951, pp. 6-7</ref>
Juan’s oldest son, [[:es:Enrique Gil y Carrasco|Enrique Gil y Carrasco]], served in the [[:es:Cristino|cristino]] army during the [[First Carlist War]]<ref>Raquel Pérez Valle, ''Biografía. D. Enrique Gil y Carrasco'', part 3: ''Su juventud'', [in:] Ricardo Gullón (ed.), ''Cisne Sin Lago. Vida y obra de Enrique Gil y Carrasco'', Madrid 1951, p. 7, available [http://perso.wanadoo.es/jlpv/vida/index_juventud.htm here]</ref> and later became one of the best known Spanish authors of [[Romanticism]]. Before moving on diplomatic mission to [[Prussia]] he worked as local tax collector; since the job was inheritable, it was taken over by Juan's younger son and the future father of Enrique, [[Eugenio Gil y Carrasco]] (1819-?). Eugenio also demonstrated some knack for letters; following premature death of his brother he edited his works and published some himself. They were intended to preserve the memory of his late sibling, though Eugenio published also poems, few dedicated to his son.<ref>Eugenio Gil, ''Un ensueño - biografia'', [in:] (ed.), G. Laverde, ''Obras de Enrique Gil'', Madrid 1855, especially a poem ''A mi hijo'', p. XXXIII, available online [http://www.bibliotecagilycarrasco.com/recursos/archivos/articulos_biblioteca/I%20Poes%C3%ADas%20l%C3%ADricas%20facs%C3%ADmil%201%C2%AA%20ed%201873.pdf here]</ref> He married Maria Robles Burruezo,<ref>Felipe Alfonso Rojas Quintana, ''Enrique Gil y Robles: la respuesta de un pensadór católico a la crisis del 98'', [in:] ''Hispania Sacra'' 53 (2001), p. 214</ref> a native of [[Málaga]].<ref>Sebastián Martín, ''Gil y Robles, Enrique (1849-1908)'' entry, [in:] ''Diccionario de catedráticos españoles de derecho (1847-1943)'' 2014, available [http://portal.uc3m.es/portal/page/portal/instituto_figuerola/programas/phu/diccionariodecatedraticos/lcatedraticos/grobles here]</ref> The couple settled in [[Salamanca]], where Eugenio continued as "administrador de rentas reales".<ref>Martín 2014</ref> [[File:José María Gil Robles.JPG|thumbnail|160px|[[José María Gil-Robles y Quiñones]]]] There is very little information available on the childhood years of the young Enrique, except that he was very early orphaned by his mother.<ref>Rojas 2001, p. 214</ref> He obtained bachillerato in Filosofía y Letras in Instituto de Segunda Enseñanza of Salamanca in 1864,<ref>Martín 2014</ref> studied law at the [[Salamanca University]] but graduated in derecho civil y canonico in [[:es:Universidad de Madrid|Universidad Central]] in 1868.<ref>in Madrid, Martín 2014</ref> Upon the 1870 foundation of Instituto de Segunda Enseñanza in Ponferrada he was employed as "profesor interino" and commenced teaching historia universal, historia de España and retórica y poética, in the early 1870s assuming also the chair of psicología, lógica y ética.<ref>Martín 2014</ref> Simultaneously he was pursuing doctoral research in [[Madrid]]; he defended the [[PhD]] thesis in 1872.<ref>Martín 2014; some sources claim the correct date is 1874, see Rojas 2001, p. 214. One of the assessors, Francisco Giner de los Ríos, was so impressed by the young scholar he visited Gil later the same day, offering him protection and friendship. Gil rejected the former and accepted the latter, which was maintained– despite sharp ideological differences – until the death of Robles, ''Revista católica de cuestiones sociales'' 163 (1908) p. 470, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002644449&page=62 here]</ref> Already a doctor, in 1875 he became full titular professor of the Ponferrada Instituto.<ref>Martín 2014</ref>
As a 45-year-old Enrique Gil Robles married Petra Quiñones Armesto,<ref>''José María Gil Robles'', [in:] ''Vida. Biografias anecdoticas'' 3 (1936), p. 3, available [http://bibliotecadigital.jcyl.es/i18n/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=10075577 here]</ref> originating from Ponferrada.<ref>Rojas 2001, p. 214</ref> The couple had 3 children, born between 1894 and 1898; the oldest son died few days after birth. The second and the youngest son, José María, as leader of [[CEDA]] became one of the best known politicians of the [[Second Spanish Republic]]; acknowledging nationwide renown of his father, he adopted the name of José María Gil-Robles y Quinones.<ref>and not José Maria Gil Quinones, as would have been usual according to the Spanish naming customs; detailed discussion of José María changing the surname in ''José María Gil Robles'', [in:] ''Vida. Biografias anecdoticas'' 3 (1936), p. 7</ref> His son and Enrique’s grandson, [[:es:José María Gil-Robles y Gil-Delgado|José María Gil-Robles y Gil-Delgado]], following the [[Spanish transition to democracy]] became one of the country leading politicians; active in Alianza Popular and [[People's Party (Spain)|Partido Popular]], in 1997-1999 he was president of the [[European Parliament]].<ref>''Excmo. Sr. Dr. D. José María Gil-Robles Gil-Delgado'', [in:] ''Real Academia de Ciencias Economicas y Financieras'' website, available [https://racef.es/es/academicosnumerario/jmgilrobles here]</ref>
==Academic== [[File:Patio de las Escuelas Menores, Universidad de Salamanca.jpg|thumbnail|left|Escuelas Menores patio, [[Salamanca University|Salamanca]]]] In 1874 Gil apparently intended to take part in contest for chairs of elementos de derecho publico y administrativo español, to be held by universities in [[Oviedo]], [[Valencia]] and [[Granada]]. Though admitted, for reasons which are not clear he did not attend the hearings.<ref>Martín 2014</ref> In July 1875 he did, however, participate in the contest for chairing cátedra de derecho político y administrativo in his native University of Salamanca, and emerged successful,<ref>Martín 2014; some sources claim in 1873, see Rojas 2001, p. 214</ref> in 1876 nominated catedrático numerario.<ref>Martín 2014</ref> He will occupy this post for the next 32 years, failing to show up at university premises only 4 days before death.<ref>''Revista católica de cuestiones sociales'' 163 (1908) p. 470</ref> The only difference in his assignment was that at some point the cátedra was split in two, and Gil continued as chair of derecho político.<ref>Martín 2014</ref>
A number of times Gil attempted to move away from Salamanca. In 1881 he was unsuccessful when applying for the same chair in [[Barcelona]]. The appeal was turned down by the ministry, but his victorious contender resigned and Gil was appointed in due course. However, shortly afterwards Gil resigned as well, quoting "unforeseen circumstances", and resumed his Salamanca duties.<ref>as the contest took place during the summer holiday period, Gil’s career in Salamanca has not been interrupted, Martín 2014</ref> In 1882-1883 he fielded his candidature for derecho publico at Universidad Central in Madrid; the attempt was unsuccessful following some repeated changes of the admission procedure, which might be interpreted as aimed against Gil.<ref>Martín 2014</ref> In 1883-1886 he applied to enter the contest for cátedra de historia del derecho at Central, but was not admitted on legal grounds; similarly, he was rejected in 1885 for literatura jurídica and in 1886 for derecho canónico, always at Central. In 1891 he resumed his attempt for historia in Madrid, again to no avail. In 1901 Gil presented his bid for chair of Estudios Superiores de Derecho penal y de Antropología criminal, again in the capital, and was again unsuccessful.<ref>it was a newly created chair within the faculty of law, Martín 2014</ref> [[File:Escuelas Mayores, Salamanca. Capilla.jpg|thumbnail|160px|university chapel]] Gil was building his academic position over time. In the early 1880s he had to suffer aggression from liberal circles both in the city and at the Salamanca university;<ref>José María Hernández Díaz, ''Maestros y escuelas en la Salamanca contemporánea'', Salamanca 2001, ISBN SBN 8495327031, esp. the sub-chapter ''Agresión a Gil Robles por un "cate" en la Universidad (1884)''</ref> as late as in the mid-1880s he was referred to as "almost unknown" in the world of Spanish law scholars.<ref>"casi desconocido", Adolfo Posada, ''Fragmentos de mis memorias'', Oviedo 1983, {{ISBN|9788474680706}}, p. 268</ref> Gradually gaining recognition, throughout his career Gil was a number of times acting as judge in numerous contests for academic chairs across Spain and took part in national juridical congresses.<ref>e.g. in 1881 in Granada, 1886 and 1888 in Barcelona or 1902 in Seville, Martín 2014, also ''El Dia'' 25.08.86, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002215447&page=2 here] or ''El Dia'' 18.08.88, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002246342&page=2 here]</ref> He was also popular among students, who appreciated his clear style combined with courtesy and benevolence.<ref>his peculiarity was the obsession to know each student personally; for picturesque description of his lectures see Rojas 2001, pp. 216-217</ref> Temporarily rising to dean of the law faculty,<ref>at unspecified time and as decano interino, temporary dean, Rojas 2001, p. 218</ref> in the early 1890s Gil, along [[Mariano Arés Sanz]], was already among the most prestigious Salamanca scholars;<ref>Posada 1983, p. 270</ref> indeed by the end of the decade together with other neo-[[Thomism|Thomists]] he dominated the Salamanca intellectual realm and was largely responsible for conservative reputation of the university.<ref>Luis Enrique Rodríguez-San Pedro Bezares, ''Historia de la Universidad de Salamanca'', vol. 1, ''Trayectoria histórica e instituciones vinculadas'', Salamanca 2002, {{ISBN|9788478001163}}, p. 254</ref> At the turn of the centuries it was rather the newcomers with pro-socialist leaning, like [[Miguel de Unamuno]], who had to struggle against overwhelmingly conservative ambience.<ref>Unamuno wrote: "esta Salamanca era por entonces, cuando yo llegué acá, uno de los más activos focos – acaso el más activo – de las luchas intestinas de la derecha antiliberal", quoted after Ana Chaguaceda Toledano, ''Miguel de Unamuno. Estudios sobre su obra'', Vol. 2, Salamanca 2005, {{ISBN|9788478005925}}, p. 74</ref> Largely aided by arrival of [[:es:Pedro Dorado Montero|Pedro Dorado Montero]], they gained ground in the 1900s,<ref>Posada 1983, p. 270</ref> though Gil Robles until his death remained an iconic Salamanca figure.<ref>Jean-Claude Rabaté, ''1900 en Salamanca. Guerra y paz en la Salamanca del joven Unamuno'', Salamanca 1997, {{ISBN|9788474818512}}, p. 15</ref>
==Works== [[File:YTB.89.43.56.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|''Tratado de derecho'']] Enrique Gil Robles was not a prolific writer; his written heritage is one major work, few booklets, a couple of articles in specialized reviews and a handful of manuscripts. He is known to have contributed to a number of periodicals, but exact scope of this activity is unclear; none of the scholarly studies consulted refers to him as "periodista".<ref>Gil is known to have contributed to ''La Informacion'' - see ''La Epoca'' 27.07.08, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000768615&page=3 here], to ''La Región'' - see José Andres Gallego, ''La politica religiosa en España'', Madrid 1975, p. 41, to ''La Tradicion'' - see Rabaté 1997, p. 170, and to ''La Tesis'', Carlos Manuel Sánchez Pérez, ''Manuel Sánchez Asensio (1860-1919) a través de los periódicos que fundó y dirigió'', [in:] ''Documentación de las Ciencias de la Información'' 30 (2007), p. 152</ref> His works fall into 3 categories: [[Political science|theory of state]], [[theory of law]] and [[pedagogy]]. Though he started writing in the early 1870s, his best known works were written and published between 1891 and 1902.
Gil’s opus magnum was ''Tratado de derecho político según los principios de la filosofía y el derecho cristianos'' (Treaty on political law according to the principles of Christian law and philosophy), published in Salamanca in two volumes respectively in 1899 and 1902. Spanning across over 1,100 pages, the work was intended to provide exhaustive lecture on organization of state in general and principles of public law in particular, though it grew into synthesis of author’s view on politics, history and religion. Two other publications, incomparable in size but far more often quoted, are two booklets: ''El absolutismo y la democracia'' (1891, containing his address opening the academic year in University of Salamanca) and ''Oligarquía y caciquismo. Naturaleza. Primeras causas. Remedios. Urgencia de ellos'' (1901). Both were formatted as lectures on problems of current Spanish politics, enveloped in wider ideological and philosophical discourse. Much less known is his early work on theory of a lawful state, ''¿Qué condiciones debe reunir la Jurisprudencia para disfrutar de la autoridad de doctrina legal?'' (1888). [[File:YTB.89.43.55.jpg|thumbnail|160px|''El catolicismo liberal'']] Among a number of works related to education the first to be named is ''El catolicismo liberal y la libertad de enseñanza'' (1896), a book comparing Catholic and liberal educational models; it developed theses laid out earlier in ''La Libertad Universitaria'' (1882).<ref>see ''La Ciencia Cristiana'' 37 (1884), available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0025478504&page=151 here]</ref> Less partisan and more technical studies were ''Ensayo de metodologia juridical'' (1893), ''Guía para el estudio del Derecho administrativo'' (1899), ''Advertencia preliminar a las "Recitaciones de Derecho Canónico y disciplina Eclesiástica de España" de Julián Portilla Martín'' (1900), ''Indicador y programa para la explicación en cátedra y la preparación fuera de ella de la asignatura de derecho político español comparado con el extranjero'' (1906), ''Método de enseñanza y programa de la asignatura de Elementos de Derecho político y administrativo español'', ''Memoria acerca del método de enseñanza, plan, y programa de la asignatura de elementos de Derecho Político y Administrativo español'' and ''Razonamiento y programa de la asignatura de Historia general del Derecho español para las oposiciones de dicha Cátedra vacante en la Universidad Central'' (all in manuscript).<ref>Gonzalo Díaz Díaz, ''Hombres y documentos de la filosofía española'', vol. 3, Madrid 1988, {{ISBN|9788400067038}}, p. 462</ref>
Gil’s written heritage is complete with very few scholarly articles on politics, education and law,<ref>''Sobre el discurso de D. Antonio Cánovas en la Academia de Ciencias Morales y Politicas'' [in:] ''La ciencia cristiana'' (Madrid pp. 5-12, 103-107, 409-417, 502-506, year 1881,) ''Otro discurso académico del Sr. Cánovas del Castillo'' (Madrid 1882 pp. 385-395, 516-526), ''De Pedagogía'' [in:] ''La España Moderna'' (1894, pp. 39-47), ''Estudios socials sobre el código civil'', [in:] ''Revista Católica de las cuestiones Sociales'' 97 (1903)</ref> one translation from German ([[Friedrich Julius Stahl]], ''Rechtsphilosophie'') and an unspecified number of pieces contributed to local and national periodicals.<ref>usually signed, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 06.11.95, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000182674&page=1 here], though also under pen names like E.G.y R., see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 21.06.99, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000208074&page=2 here]</ref> None of his works was issued again until 1961, when ''Tratado de derecho politico'' was re-edited by a Madrid publishing house.<ref>by Casa Afrodisio Aguado and with punctuation corrected by Pablo Beltrán de Heredia</ref> One present-day student refers to his opus as "very ample".<ref>Rojas 2001, p. 219</ref>
==Thought== [[File:JuanDonosoCortes.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|[[Juan Donoso Cortés|Donoso]] by [[:es:Germán Hernández Amores|Hernandez]]]] Some suggest that Gil’s doctrine formed part of [[regenerationism]] and was largely a response to the [[American-Spanish War|1898 disaster]];<ref>like Rojas</ref> most scholars claim that his thought continued earlier 19th Traditionalist works, especially those of [[Juan Donoso Cortés|Donoso Cortés]], and developed mostly as reaction to the [[Glorious Revolution (Spain)|1868 revolution]].<ref>like García Canales, Gonzalez Cuevas or Montoro Ballesteros</ref> All students agree that Gil diagnosed the key malady of Spain as [[Liberalism in Spain|Liberalism]], which destroyed traditional structures and replaced them with [[bourgeoisie]] [[oligarchy]], exercised systematically by means of industry and trade and personally by the network of [[:es:Caciquismo (España)|caciques]].<ref>Rojas 2001, pp. 219-20</ref> The prescription advocated was reversal to the spirit and partially institutions of [[Ancien Régime|Antiguo Régimen]];<ref>Rojas 2001, p. 222</ref> two key elements of Gil’s vision were organic society and sovereign king.<ref>Mariano García Canales, ''La democracia y el repliegue del individuo: organicismo y corporativismo'', [in:] ''Espacio, Tiempo y Forma'' 27 (2015), p. 26</ref>
According to Gil men, who are not equally free and sovereign, form part of different groups.<ref>Manuel Alberto Montoro Ballesteros, ''La idea de democracia en el pensamiento de don Enrique Gil y Robles'', [in:] ''Revista de estudios políticos'' 174 (1970), p. 100</ref> Though being individuals, they are expressed by activity in various social entities and in the overall structure.<ref>Gil pursued a concept of dual relationship, as an individual is linked to groups he belongs to and to the entire society, Mariano García Canales, ''La teoría de la representación en la España del siglo XX: (de la crisis de la restauración a 1936)'', Madrid 1977, {{ISBN|9788460010531}}, p. 45, García Canales (2015), p. 25</ref> Society is not a sum of individuals, but a structure made of these groups; comparison to a living body consisting of vital organic wholes gave rise to the term "organic society", a pluralist and gradualist structure.<ref>Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''Tradicionalismo, catolicismo y nacionalismo'', [in:] ''Ayer'' 71 (2008), p. 32</ref> All groups retain their internal autonomy;<ref>García Canales 1977, pp. 38, 43-4</ref> in Gil’s nomenclature it was referred to as "autarquia"<ref>José J. Albert Márquez, ''Hacia un estado corporativo de justicia. Fundamentos del derecho y del estado en José Pedro Galvao de Sousa'', Barcelona 2010, {{ISBN|9788415929284}}, p. 99</ref> and stood for self-government.<ref>Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis in Historia Contemporanea, Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Valencia 2009, p. 367</ref> Society consists of 3 layers: noble class, middle class and working class, each with own roles and functions,<ref>Montoro Ballesteros 1970, p. 93, Rojas 2001, p. 224</ref> though there are also other horizontal and vertical lines making various groups distinct.<ref>horizontal ones are mostly territorial: family, municipio, region, province etc, while vertical are mostly functional, like gremios, asociaciones, parties etc., Garcia Canales 1977, p. 46, García Canales 2015, p. 26</ref> Democracy<ref>the term was used by Gil literally, as "democracia"</ref> is not a political regime, but a constituting principle of such a society;<ref>Montoro Ballesteros 1970, p. 92</ref> it means recognition of roles performed by various groups and of their internal sovereignty,<ref>"Llamemos, pues, democracia al total estado jurídico del pueblo, es decir, a la condición que resulta del reconocimiento, garantía y goce de todos los derechos privados, públicos y políticos que corresponden a la clase popular, la cual, si no es soberana, es también imperante y gobernante en proporción de su valor y fuerza sociales", quoted after Montoro Ballesteros 1970, p. 93</ref> which at times might include the right to coerce.<ref>"el derecho que corresponde a la persona superior de una sociedad para obligar a los miembros de ella a los actos conducentes al fin social, en cuanto, por naturaleza o circunstancias, sean incapaces esos miembros de ordenarse a dicho fin o bien", quoted after Montoro Ballesteros 1970, p. 95</ref> Society is held together by interdependence of its components and not by any [[social contract]]; contracts, by definition voluntary, temporary and reversible, would make such a commonality absurd.<ref>García Canales 2015, p. 26</ref> [[File:Herrera thomas aquinas.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Aquinas]] by [[Francisco Herrera the Younger|Herrera]]]] Political representation is performed not by [[universal suffrage]],<ref>which was deemed as dictatorship of the plebs ("plebe"), Montoro Ballesteros 1970, pp. 99-100</ref> which is anti-democratic as it unduly elevates individual self<ref>Montoro Ballesteros 1970, p. 95</ref> and gives rise to corruption and political oligarchy, but is to be channeled along corporative lines.<ref>Garcia Canales 1977, p. 46, García Canales 2015, p. 26</ref> The diet – named "organicista"<ref>Javier Ordoñez, ''Utopía y distopía en el XIX español'', [in:] Manuel Suárez Cortina (ed.), ''Utopías, quimeras, y desencantos: el universo utópico en la España liberal'', Oviedo 2008, {{ISBN|9788481024821}}, pp. 38-9</ref> or "corporatista"<ref>Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''Las tradiciones ideológicas de la extrema derecha española'', [in:] ''Hispania'' 207 (2001), p. 119</ref> - is to be entrusted with legislative initiative and consulting tasks.<ref>García Canales 2015, p. 26</ref> It should consist of two chambers. The lower one is to host territorial and labor entities, the upper one is to be made of selected and noble nominees.<ref>Garcia Canales 1977, p. 47</ref>
The idea of state should be based on "monarquía bajomedieval",<ref>Rojas 2001, p. 222</ref> a withdrawn structure<ref>Rojas 2001, p. 220</ref> which performs only basic roles and cedes most governing to its social components.<ref>Rojas 2001, p. 222; Gil strongly opposed the idea of omnipotent state, advancing theory of autarquic societies versus institutional power, Suárez Cortina 2008, pp. 38-9</ref> The rise of potent state – like most European countries of the late 19th century, Spain included - was due to decomposition of the society, unable to govern itself. In case of sane society, the state structure should be topped by a sovereign, a person (monarchy) rather than entity (poliarquia),<ref>influenced by Karl Ludwig van Haller and Luigi Taparelli, Montoro Ballesteros 1970, pp. 96, 100</ref> limited in his powers by autarquia of social groupings, but enjoying political sovereignty – Gil rejected [[separation of powers]] into legislative, executive and juridical,<ref>Montoro Ballesteros 1970, pp. 96, 98</ref> though he distinguished between social and political sovereignty.<ref>Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''Tradicionalismo'', [in:] Javier Fernández Sebastián (ed.), ''Diccionario político y social del siglo XX español'', Madrid 2008, {{ISBN|9788420687698}}, p. 1163</ref> He dismissed absolutist<ref>as cesarist, Rojas 2001, p. 221</ref> and constitutional<ref>Gil distinguished between two types of constitutional monarchy: monarquía democrática (Spain according to the 1869 constitution; its article 32 declared sovereignty of the nation and assigned executive role to the king) or monarquía doctrinaria (Spain according to the 1876 constitution; its article 18 declared that powers reside jointly with Cortes and king), Montoro Ballesteros 1970, pp. 101-2</ref> monarchy alike. However, in extremis he was prepared to endorse coercion<ref>Cristóbal Robles, Cristóbal Robles Muñoz, ''José María de Urquijo e Ybarra: opinión, religión y poder'', Madrid 1997, {{ISBN|9788400076689}}, p. 73</ref> and admitted that dictatorial monarchy was acceptable as a last resort.<ref>Rojas 2001, p. 221 Javier Esteve Martí, ''El carlismo ante la reorganización de las derechas. De la Segunda Guerra Carlista a la Guerra Civil'', [in:] ''Revista de Historia Contemporánea'' 13 (2014), pp. 128-9</ref>
==Politician== [[File:Ramon Nocedal.JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|[[Ramón Nocedal Romea|Ramón Nocedal]], 1880s]] None of the sources consulted clarifies how Gil adopted a conservative outlook.<ref>Salamanca city and province were by no means a Carlist stronghold, though the movement retained significant force to be accounted for; it was powered by "notables rurales: medianos propietarios del campo, algunos comerciantes de relieve, pequeño artesanado y el añadido de unos profesionales liberales concentrados básicamente en la capital y en algunas cabezas de partido", Leopoldo-Santiago Diez Cano, ''Carlismo en Salamanca en el sexenio: notas sobre un movimiento "marginal"'', [in:] ''Studia historica. Historia contemporánea'' 4 (1986). pp. 43-4</ref> Having been eyewitness to excesses of the 1868 revolution in Madrid he might have been influenced by the [[:es:Neocatólico|neocatólicos]], especially that he forged a close relationship with [[Ramón Nocedal Romea|Ramón Nocedal]]. In 1869 co-founder of local Juventud Católica,<ref>Diez Cano 1986. p. 46</ref> starting 1870 he was delivering addresses with strong Traditionalist leaning and was quoted by Carlist newspapers.<ref>like ''La Regeneración'' 03.05.70, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026691172&page=2 here], ''La Regeneración'' 22.05.70, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026691485&page=2 here]</ref> No source confirms (or denies) that he took part in the [[Third Carlist War]], though some obituaries ambiguously claim that he "led the brave youth of Salamanca [...] fighting to defend Spain" of his ideal;<ref>"figuró á la cabeza de aquella brava y animosa juventud salmantina que, respondiendo corno á una solemne evocación del espíritu de nuestra raza, peleaba con denuedo en defensa de la España de sus amores y de la religión de sus padres", ''Revista católica de cuestiones sociales'' 163 (1908) p. 469</ref> it remains mysterious why he failed to attend 1874 hearings for academic posts he signed up to.<ref>Martín 2014</ref>
Gil remained active in Juventud also after 1876,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 09.03.78, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000030491&page=1 here]</ref> and in late 1870s continued in its Salamanca executive.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 17.12.78, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000039319&page=2 here], also ''El Siglo Futuro'' 15.12.79, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000048556&page=1 here]; one source claims that as one of the Madrid Juventud Católica leaders he was offered a place in the Cortes by Canovas, the only string attached that he did not endorse the rights of Carlos VII; Gil allegedly refused, ''Revista católica de cuestiones sociales'' 163 (1908) p. 470</ref> Engaged in broad Traditionalist movement, he prepared a massive 1882 pilgrimage to [[Rome]]<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 17.01.82, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000060121&page=2 here]; the initiative was soon dissolved as pressed by the episcopal authorities, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 20.02.82, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000061161&page=2 here]</ref> and co-signed letters of support, addressed to ecclesiastical hierarchs and animated by the Nocedals.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 07.04.85, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000089157&page=1 here] also ''El Siglo Futuro'' 26.05.85, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000090660&page=1 here]</ref> Gil participated also in clearly Carlist initiatives, like 1883 attempt to build a monument of [[Zumalacarregui]],<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 03.03.83, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000066890&page=1 here]</ref> published in Carlist press<ref>mostly ''La Tradicion'' (subtitled Dios, Patria y Rey), issued in 1886, Rabaté 1997, p. 170</ref> and in the mid-1880s was already among leaders of the Salmantine Traditionalism.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 12.05.83, [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000069018&page=2 here]</ref> In 1886, he was rumored to run on the Carlist ticket for the [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]],<ref>''La Dinastia'' 06.02.88, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001428122&page=10 here]</ref> but the party eventually decided to maintain their abstention strategy. [[File:Don Carlos de Borbón, en Nuevo Mundo.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Carlos VII]], 1898]] During the 1888 crisis Gil decided to join the breakaway Nocedal-led [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrists]],<ref>Javier Real Cuesta, ''El carlismo vasco 1876–1900'', Madrid 1985, {{ISBN|9788432305108}}, p. 113</ref> signing up to ''Manifesto de Búrgos''.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 07.11.88, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000127757&page=2 here]</ref> In 1889 Gil was among organizers of their [[Partido Tradicionalista]], but did not enter its executive.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 01.08.89, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000135479&page=1 here]</ref> In [[Spanish general election, 1891|1891]] he ran as Integrist for the Cortes in the [[Sequeros]] district;<ref>''La Unión Católica'' 29.01.91, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004885652&page=3 here]; Sequeros was the most Carlist district of the province, some 26% of the party militants used to come from the area, Diez Cano 1986, p. 36</ref> initially reported victorious,<ref>''El Liberal'' 03.02.91, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001209191&page=2 here]</ref> he was finally declared defeated<ref>see the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDBuscHisDip?_piref73_1340033_73_1340032_1340032.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXDSP.fmt&DOCS=4-4&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%40ELEN%26gt%3B%3D%2237%22+%26+%40ELEN%26lt%3B%3D%2242%22+%26+%28%22SEQUEROS%22%29.DIST. here]</ref> and did not renew his bid in the following [[Spanish general election, 1893|campaign of 1893]]. During run-up to the [[Spanish general election, 1896|1896 campaign]] he led the provincial junta electoral<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 15.10.95, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000182380&page=5 here]</ref> but did not run himself. At that time his relations with Nocedal were cooling down.<ref>around 1897 ''El Siglo Futuro'' ceased to publish his articles and to advertise his books</ref> Apart from other reasons,<ref>initially cordial relationship between Nocedal and Gil, forged in the late 1860s, started to crack allegedly in 1891-1892, when Nocedal refused to appeal to the Roman Rota protesting episcopal measures against ''La Región'', José M. Cuenca Toribio, ''Otras memorias jesuíticas de la Restauración'', [in:] ''Anales de Historia Contemporánea'' 1 (1982), p. 168</ref> Gil was allegedly uncomfortable with virulent Integrist campaign against the Carlist claimant.<ref>Cuenca Toribio 1982, p. 168</ref> In early 1899 Gil attempted to arrange reconciliation between mainstream Carlists and the Integrists, but was greeted with ice cold response of Nocedal.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 21.06.99, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000208074&page=2 here]</ref> Later that year the two broke altogether,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 30.06.99, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000208268&page=2 here]</ref> their public altercation cheered by the Republican press.<ref>which mocked Gil by referring to him as "catedrático de Salamanca por desgracia de la juventud española", ''El País'' 12.07.99, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001873695&page=1 here]</ref>
Having left Integrism Gil returned to "vieja mansión" of mainstream Carlism;<ref>Cuenca Toribio 1982, p. 153, Román Oyarzun, ''Historia del carlismo'', Madrid 1969, p. 511</ref> following 1899 exchange of cordial letters with [[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Carlos VII]]<ref>Gil wrote in November 1899: "Señor: No encuentro palabras bastante expresivas con que manifestar a V. M. La gratitud de que le soy deudor. El regio autógrafo con que V. M. se ha dignado honrarme, sería sobrada recompensa de los más ilustres y heroicos servicios a la Causa de Dios, de la Patria y del Rey, no habiendo tenido yo la dicha de prestarlos; mas obligado quedo a consagrarme a ella sin reserva ni restricción alguna, para que los renglones trazados de la real mano sean merecida ejecutoria de lealtad que transmitir sin mancha a mis hijos. Hora es ya de que no haya más que un programa y una hueste bajo la Cruz triunfadora de todas las desventuras y catástrofes bajo la Monarquía cristiana, que hoy, como después del Guadalete, es la única institución que flota sobre el naufragio", to which Carlos VII responded: "Mi querido Gil Robles: Quiero ponerte yo mismo dos letras, pues arrepentimientos y retractaciones como las tuyas prueban, además de un espíritu recto y elevado, un gran corazón. Cuento contigo, y quiera Dios que muchos de los engañados abran los ojos y sigan tan noble ejemplo, para bien de nuestra querida y tan desgraciada España. Tu afectísimo, Carlos", quoted after Maximiliano Garcia Venero, ''Historia de la Unificacion'', Madrid 1970, p. 18</ref> he started to publish in semi-official party daily ''Correo Español'',<ref>Cuenca Toribio 1982, p. 168</ref> though he did not enter the party structures. For some time in 1901-1902 he kept working for reconciliation.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 12.11.01, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000226822&page=2 here]</ref> In [[Spanish general election, 1903|1903]] he renewed his Cortes bid,<ref>declining the offer of having been appointed to Senate by the Salamanca academics, ''Revista católica de cuestiones sociales'' 163 (1908) p. 470</ref> this time almost assured victory in the Carlist-dominated [[Pamplona]].<ref>see the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2846940%29.NDIP. here]</ref> In the diet he became the spokesman of the Carlist minority<ref>Jesús Millán, ''La Retopía del carlismo: referentes y márgenes ideológicos'', [in:] Manuel Suárez Cortina, ''Utopías, quimeras, y desencantos: el universo utópico en la España liberal'', Oviedo 2008, {{ISBN|9788481024821}}, p 255, Rojas 2001, p. 225; in the Cortes Gil earned the nickname Don Tancredo, a reference to a peculiar bullfighting technique, Posada 1983, p. 269</ref> and until 1905 was fairly frequently reported by the press as active on a variety of issues,<ref>some considered him too elegant and subtle for the Cortes business: "D. Enrique; es usted muy puro para vivir en este ambiente", quoted after Revista católica de cuestiones sociales 163 (1908) p. 470</ref> ranging from education<ref>''El Globo'' 11.07.08, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001246761&page=3 here]</ref> to Catalan question,<ref>''El Liberal'' 11.07.08, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001414310&page=2 here], also Evarist Olcina, ''El Carlismo y las autonomías regionales'', Madrid 1974, p. 197, Andres Gallego 1975, p. 338, [[Melchor Ferrer Dalmau|Melchor Ferrer]], ''Historia del legitimismo español'', vol. XXX, Sevilla 1979, p. 89</ref> legal order,<ref>''El Día'' 17.07.03, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002464041&page=3 here]</ref> organization of trade,<ref>e.g. speaking against working on Sundays, ''El Día'' 05.11.03, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002468417&page=2 here]</ref> foreign policy,<ref>''El Día'' 26.11.03, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002469478&page=3 here], the same episode (despatching a Spanish warship on courtesy visit to the United States) discussed in Rojas 2001, pp. 224-6</ref> internal rules of the Congress<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 26.11.03, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000242306&page=2 here]</ref> and religion.<ref>''La Dinastia'' 12.06.04, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001767070&page=2 here]</ref> He did not run in the 1905 and 1907 elections and remained rather loosely involved in internal Carlist politics,<ref>e.g. Gil Robles is not a single time mentioned in massive dissertation on marqués de Cerralbo as a Carlist leader, in length discussing Carlist politics of the 1890s and 1900s, Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845–1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis], Madrid 2012</ref> but kept publishing in ''Correo Español''.<ref>and maintaining firmly reaccionary stand, e.g. when discussing the Russian revolution of 1905, see ''El Imparcial'' 07.03.05, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000868523&page=1 here]</ref>
==''Salmantino''== [[File:Tomás de Cámara y Castro.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|[[Tomás Cámara y Castro]]]] Gil was active in many fields of the Salmantine realm. In 1883 he entered the local Comisión de Reformas Sociales;<ref>Rabaté 1997, p. 107</ref> in 1887 he was admitted as member-correspondent to Académia de Legislación y Jurisprudencia de Salamanca;<ref>Martín 2014</ref> in 1893 he was voted into the city [[ayuntamiento]], where he led the conservative faction; this council was dubbed "ayuntamiento de notables";<ref>Rabaté 1997, pp. 157-8</ref> in 1894 he was vice-president of the Salamancan Liga de Productores;<ref>and lobbied in favor of protective measures against foreign imports, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 03.01.95, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000179344&page=2 here]</ref> in 1902<ref>having received the official title of consejero de instrucción publica. In 1901, in recognition of his merits in education, he was offered high posts in administration, the proposal rejected as he decided not to accept assignements beyond his academic path, Martín 2014</ref> he was nominated to Consejo Universitario in Salamanca<ref>Martín 2014</ref> and other provincial educational bodies<ref>Posada 1983, p. 270</ref> and in 1903 he was proposed to represent the province in the [[Senate (Spain)|Senate]], delegated by the University.<ref>but declined opting for running on a Carlist ticket to the lower chamber of the diet, Rojas 2001, p. 218</ref> He contributed to Salmantine Traditionalist periodicals, first ''La Tesis'',<ref>an intransigent periodical issued in 1885-1886 by Manuel Sánchez Asensio. He wrote: "Tendremos respeto, tolerancia y caridad para las personas. Seremos inflexibles e intransigentes con las miserias y los vicios", the latter a reference to liberalism, Sánchez Pérez 2007, p. 152</ref> then ''La Región'' and finally ''La Información''.<ref>''La Región'' was issued in Salamanca between 1890 and 1892, ''La Información'' between 1892 and 1897, Sánchez Pérez 2007, p. 159</ref> However, Gil left his trademark on the Salmantine life by means of two long-lasting conflicts with other local personalities.
The intransigent Integrists clashed with the Spanish ecclesiastical hierarchy, which advocated the platform of Catholic unity, almost from the onset, which finally led to calling off the 1882 pilgrimage to Rome.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 20.02.82, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000061161&page=2 here]</ref> Locally the conflict was aggravated with the 1885 arrival of the new Salamanca bishop, [[Tomás Cámara y Castro]], a hierarch described as posibilista,<ref>Sánchez Pérez 2007, p 153; he declared acceptance of art. 11 of the 1876 constitution, which set a new model of church-state relations, and adhered to the "hypothesis" theory, logical pillar of the "Catholic unity" strategy, Posada 1983, pp. 268-9</ref> moderado and aperturista.<ref>Mariano Esteban de Vega, ''Católicos contra liberales notas sobre el ambiente ideológico salmantino en la Restauración'', [in:] ''Studia historica. Historia contemporánea'' 4 (1986), p. 51</ref> He launched onslaught on fundamentalist line of local Traditionalist periodicals,<ref>Posada 1983, p. 269</ref> which soon led to an open press war;<ref>de Vega 1986, p. 51</ref> the most distinguished representative of Salmantine Integros, supported by the local [[Jesuits]],<ref>"jesuitas de la Clerecía", Claude Rabaté 1997, pp. 169-170</ref> was Gil, dubbed "prohombre" of "camarilla jesuítica antiepiscopal".<ref>Sánchez Pérez 2007, p. 166</ref> The conflict climaxed in 1892, when Cámara banned local Catholics from reading ''La Región''<ref>''La Unión Católica'' 05.04.92, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004892411&page=1 here]; the episcopal order read: "esta prohibición se extiende, mientras otra cosa no ordenáramos, á cualquier papel periódico que redactaren D. Manuel Sánchez Asensio ó D. Enrique Gil y Robles"</ref> and all periodicals edited by Manuel Sánchez Asensio and Gil Robles.<ref>Andres Gallego 1975, p. 41</ref> The latter fought back appealing to Rome,<ref>Rabaté 1997, p. 179, Cuenca Toribio 1982, p. 168</ref> kept referring to the bishop with venomous irony<ref>Rabaté 1997, p. 183</ref> and confronted him as late as in 1895.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 24.01.95, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000179558&page=1 here]</ref> In the late 1890s the conflict scaled down as Gil moved away from Integrism and Cámara turned his ally in showdown against liberal University scholars. [[File:Miguel de Unamuno 1912.png|thumbnail|160px|[[Miguel de Unamuno]]]] After 1891 death of Mariano Arés Sanz the Salmantine academic realm was almost entirely dominated by conservatives like Gil Robles, [[Alejandro de la Torre Vélez]] and [[Nicasio Sánchez Mata]].<ref>Rodríguez-San Pedro Bezares 2002, p, 254</ref> It was exactly the funeral of Arés which produced confrontation with Miguel de Unamuno, then a young professor of [[Greek language|Greek]] freshly landed in Salamanca.<ref>1891 signed a letter supporting the idea of denying funeral academic honors to Ares, quoting law which prevented honors other than those compliant with Religión del Estado, Rabaté 1997, p. 136</ref> Gil’s address opening the 1891-2 course elicited another backlash, which took shape of 5 Unamuno’s articles titled ''Un nocedalino desquiciado''.<ref>Rabaté 1997, pp. 147-8</ref> Written in very aggressive language quite untypical for public disputes between academics of the era, they denounced Gil as a reactionary intending to galvanize the long dead [[Middle Ages]]; Unamuno lambasted his opponent as "inepto, mediocre y indocto" and his address as "sudado, artificioso, falso, manera y no estilo".<ref>Rabaté 1997, p. 149</ref> Later on Unamuno backtracked, at least in terms of tone,<ref>Rabaté 1997, p. 151</ref> but relations between the two remained tense.<ref>Rojas 2001, p. 213</ref> Unamuno soon found an ally in another newcomer academic, Pedro Dorado Montero, in 1897 endangered not only by expulsion from the university, but also by excommunication;<ref>the issue was a so-called "Tercera cuestión universitaria" (teaching in line with Catholic outlook); in 1897 students denounced Montero as not adhering to the religious principles. Camara demanded that Dorada be expulsed, but the rector quoted constitutional stipulation that no-one will be persecuted for his religious outlook, Rojas 2001, p. 218, Sánchez Pérez 2007, pp. 164-6</ref> the two kept reclaiming the local academic realm from the conservatives, the task largely completed after the death of Gil Robles.<ref>Ana Chaguaceda Toledano, ''Miguel de Unamuno. Estudios sobre su obra'', vol. 2, Salamanca 2005, {{ISBN|9788478005925}}, pp. 74-75. For an overview of Unamuno's somewhat complex and ambiguous stance towards Carlism see Jordi Canal, ''Un gran episodio nacional: Unamuno, el carlismo y las guerras civiles'', [in:] Ana Chaguaceda Toledano (ed.), ''Miguel de Unamuno estudio sobre su obra IV: actas de las VII Jornadas unamunianas'', Salamanca 2009, {{ISBN|9788478002931}}, pp. 207-214 and Jean-Claude Rabaté, ''Miguel de Unamuno y el carlismo'', [in:] ''Imágenes: el Carlismo en las artes. III Jornadas de Estudio del Carlismo'', Estella 2010, {{ISBN|9788423532278}}, pp. 13-28</ref>
==Reception and legacy== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] By the end of his life Gil emerged as key Traditionalist thinker and gained a prestigious scholarly position;<ref>according to Francisco Giner de los Ríos, Gil "era el escritor y pensador de más sólida formación de la escuela católica española en lo referente a las ciencas políticas", quoted after Posada 1983, pp. 268-9, and his ''Tratado de Derecho Politico'' was above anything written in Catholic Hispanic literature, Rojas 2001, p. 215</ref> however, he did not make it to the top elite of Spanish law academics, as certified by his failures to obtain a chair in Madrid.<ref>he has also never entered Real Academia de Jurisprudencia y Legislación</ref> Following death<ref>he died due to [[hemiparesis]] and his death reverberated in the press of the era, for review of obituaries see ''Revista católica de cuestiones sociales'' 163 (1908) p. 470 and onwards</ref> his memory was first eclipsed and later relegated into oblivion by prolific activity of another Carlist theorist, [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]].<ref>José Luis Orella Martínez, ''El origen del primer Catolicismo social Español'', [PhD thesis, Universidad de Educación a Distancia], Madrid 2012, pp. 36-7</ref> In the 1930s his image was reduced further on to merely "a father of José Maria Gil-Robles". After the [[Spanish Civil War|war]] neither the [[Francoism|regime]] nor any other political grouping admitted deference to Gil. During revival of the Carlist doctrine in the late Francoist era its key theorists focused on de Mella and referred to Gil casually,<ref>see e.g. the writings of [[Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spínola|Francisco Elias de Tejada]] or [[Rafael Gambra Ciudad|Rafael Gambra]]. The sole post-war Traditionalist scholar who ventured to develop some threads of Gil’s work was [[Marcial Solana González-Camino|Marcial Solana]]; he focused on the autarchy thesis, Jacek Bartyzel, ''Nic bez Boga, nic wbrew tradycji'', Radzymin 2015, {{ISBN|9788360748732}}, pp. 113, 189–201</ref> though he was acknowledged as one of the giants of Traditionalism.<ref>see the 1970 booklet ''¿Que es el carlismo?'', available [http://www.carlismo.es/librosElectronicos/queeselcarlismo.pdf here], p. 10</ref> Following transición Traditionalism went dramatically out of fashion and a present-day student refers to Gil as "unknown figure, unjustly forgotten".<ref>"figura desconocida, injustamente olvidado", Rojas 2001, pp. 213, 227</ref> Apart from an unpublished 1969 PhD thesis and a handful of articles, he has earned no major monograph so far.
In the current scholarly discourse as a law theorist Gil is classified as 'iusnaturalista" belonging either to the neo-scholastic<ref>''Indice Historico Espanol'' Vol. XVIII no 65, Barcelona 1972, p. 451</ref> or neo-thomist school,<ref>Montoro Ballesteros, ''Filosofia y estilo de vida: apunte biografico y perfil intelectual del profesor Mariano Hurtado Bautista'', [in:] Antonio Perez Martin (ed.), ''Funciones y fines del derecho: estudios en homenaje al profesor Mariano Hurtado Bautista'', Murcia 1992, {{ISBN|9788476843260}}, p. 23</ref> indebted to [[Luigi Taparelli]], [[José Prisco (1835-1923)|José Prisco]]<ref>Antonio Enrique Pérez Luño, ''El derecho natural en la España del siglo XX'', [in:] F. Puig (ed.), ''El Derecho Natural Hispánico'', Madrid 1973, p. 134</ref> and [[Luis Mendizábal Martín (1859-1931)|Luis Mendizabal Martín]].<ref>Pérez Luño 1973, p. 138</ref> In dedicated works on natural law in Spain he is treated either marginally<ref>compare Pérez Luño 1973, pp. 140-1</ref> or not at all,<ref>Enrique Pérez Luño, ''Natural law theory in Spain and Portugal'', [in:] ''The Age of Human Rights Journal'' 1 (2013), pp. 1-24</ref> though some authors appreciate his original contribution.<ref>namely his elaboration of monistic "derecho objetivo" (aimed against duality of public and private law), noted by Albert Márquez 2010, p. 99, and distinction between derecho natural divino, a natural attribute of a being, and derecho natural adventicio, appearing in cases and deeds created by human activity, distinction which enables historic projection of natural law and which relates to doctrine of Francisco Suárez and his differentiating between lex (ius naturale praeceptivum) and dominium (ius naturale dominativum), - Pérez Luño 1973, pp. 140-1; detailed discussion of Suárez concept in J. A. Fernández-Santamaría, ''Natural Law, Constitutionalism, Reason of State, and War: Counter-reformation Spanish Political Thought'', vol. 1, Madrid 2005, {{ISBN|9780820474274}}, p. 132</ref> As a theorist of education he is presented as representative of Catholic fundamentalism,<ref>education is to be managed by the Church, which guarantees unity and spirit of the nation, Rojas 2001, p 222</ref> enemy of [[krausism]] and heterodoxy.<ref>Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''Las tradiciones ideológicas de la extrema derecha española'', Hispania 207 (2001), p. 119</ref> As a state theorist he is usually referred to as Traditionalist,<ref>one of "doctrinarios de tradicionalismo carlista" (Orella Martínez 2012, p. 449), "teoretico del tradicionalismo" (Juan Rodríguez Ruiz, José María Benavente Barreda, ''Tradicionalismo'', [in:] ''Enciclopedia de la Cultura Española'', Madrid 1968, pp. 456-459), also García Canales 2015, p 25, González Cuevas 2008, p. 1165; some claim that Gil "offers fruitful and original synthesis of neothomism and traditionalism" (Díaz Díaz 1988, p. 462. A peculiar approach is demonstrated by a historian militant in progressist Partido Carlista, who claims that Traiditonalists were aliens who infiltrated the genuine Carlism, compare José Carlos Clemente Muñoz, ''El carlismo en el novecientos español (1876-1936)'', Madrid 1999, {{ISBN|9788483741535}}, p. 56</ref> sometimes also as "organicista",<ref>José Manuel Roca, ''La derecha furiosa'', Madrid 2005, {{ISBN|9788493447472}}, p. 161</ref> "católico tradicional"<ref>Rojas 2001, p. 213</ref> or representative of "corporativismo católico".<ref>Laureano López Rodó, ''Memorias'', Madrid 1990, {{ISBN|9788478630097}}, p. 143</ref> As a politician Gil is typically labeled either as Carlist<ref>Gonzalo Alvarez Chillida, ''El antisemitismo en España: la imagen del judío, 1812-2002'', Madrid 2002, {{ISBN|9788495379443}}, p. 227, José Andrés-Gallego, Antón M. Pazos, ''La Iglesia en la España contemporánea 1800-1936'', Madrid 1999, {{ISBN|9788474905199}}, p. 216, José Andrés Gallego, ''Historia general de España y América'', Madrid 1982, {{ISBN|9788432121135}}, p. 694, Eric Storm, ''La perspectiva del progreso: Pensamiento político en la España del cambio de siglo (1890-1914)'', Madrid 2001, {{ISBN|9788470309090}}, p. 134, Paul Preston, ''Coming of the Spanish Civil War : Reform, Reaction and Revolution in The Second Republic'', Barcelona 2001, {{ISBN|9788425335990}}, p. 102, Cristián Garay Vera, ''El tradicionalismo y los orígenes de la guerra civil española (1927-1937)'', Santiago de Chile 1987, p. 96.. Some scholars classify Gil (along Matías Barrio, Pascual Comín, Salvador Minguión, Bartolomé Feliú and others) as representative of "academic" Carlism, Bartyzel 2015, p. 12</ref> or Integrist.<ref>Alberto Gil Novales, ''Centenario de la "información de 1901" del Ateneo de Madrid sobre "oligarquía y caciquismo"'', Madrid 2003, {{ISBN|9788424509194}}, p. 140, Chaguaceda Toledano 2005, p. 74, Rabaté 1997, pp. 114-5, Luciano G. Egido, ''Salamanca, la gran metáfora de Unamuno'', Salamanca 1983, {{ISBN|9788474812435}}, p. 19, Dolores Gómez Molleda, ''Unamuno "agitador de espiritus" y Giner de los Ríos'', Salamanca 1976, {{ISBN|9788460069089}}, p. 11, Posada 1983, p. 221, José Javier López Antón, ''Arturo Campión entre la historia y la cultura'', Pamplona 1998, {{ISBN|9788423517879}}, p. 106. Some refer to Gil as "ora integrista, ora carlista", see Victor Manuel Arbeloa, ''El quiebro del PSOE (1933-1934)'', vol. 1, ''Del gobierno a la revolución'', Madrid 2015, {{ISBN|9788415705642}}, pp. 98-99</ref> As a public figure he is considered a reactionary.<ref>"postura inequívocamente reaccionaria" (Ángel Menéndez Rexach, ''La jefatura del Estado en el derecho público español'', Barcelona 1979, p. 199), "uno de los más reaccionarios" scholars in Salamanca (Víctor Ouimette, ''Los intelectuales españoles y el naufragio del liberalismo, 1923-1936'', v. 1, Madrid 1998, {{ISBN|9788481911770}}, p. 246), "Católico reaccionario" (Manuel José Alonso García, ''Temas y protagonistas del pensamiento español del siglo XX'', v. 1, Madrid 2003, {{ISBN|9788492177417}}, p. 113)</ref> According to his son<ref>who was orphaned by his father at the age of 10</ref> he was "a democrat to the core";<ref>"demócrata en lo más profundo del alma", which does not prevent José María from calling his father "inquebrantable carlista", José María Gil-Robles, ''No fue possible la paz'', Barcelona 1968, p. 20. He also declared that only lack of overt monarchism divided CEDA from Traditionalism, Garcia Canales 2015, p. 68</ref> José María Gil-Robles admitted having been politically indebted to his father,<ref>during one of his Cortes addresses In the early 1930s a Carlist deputy exclaimed: "this is Traditionalism!", to which Gil-Robles responded by stating that the Carlists did not possess exclusive rights to Traditionalism</ref> but their visions of [[Christian democracy]] were entirely incompatible.<ref>Gil Robles viewed first papal references to Christian democracy as "acción social benéfica", sort of Catholic social actitivity and by no means acceptance of "the people" as a political sovereign, Montoro 1970, pp. 105-7. This approach to papal introduction of the term was fairly typical among Catholic conservatives first faced with the papal initiative, see Jacek Bartyzel, ''Demokracja chrześcijańska a konserwatyści (w świetle nauczania papieskiego)'', [in:] Jacek Bartyzel, ''Śmiertelny bóg demos'', Warszawa 2009, {{ISBN|9788389812148}}, pp. 136-144. Another interpretation offered is that Gil viewed christian democracy as recognition that pueblo (hierarchized) shared sovereignty with a monarch, González Cuevas 2001, p. 119</ref>
Scholars differ when assessing Gil’s contribution to Traditionalism. In a very recent historiographical synthesis of the theory he is treated marginally;<ref>there are 7 rather casual references in Bartyzel 2015; in comparison, Vázquez de Mella is mentioned 67 times</ref> some see him as merely a "sistematizador" of earlier thought;<ref>mostly Balmes, Cortes and Aparisi - Garcia Canales 1977, p. 44, García Canales 2015, p 25</ref> others view him as a theorist who re-modeled the ideology<ref>"remodelar los planteamientos del tradicionalismo", Javier Ugarte Tellería, ''El Nacionalismo vasco: Mitos, conmemoraciones y lugares de la memoria'', Madrid 2006, {{ISBN|9788497425513}}, p. 258</ref> and one of the all-time Traditionalist greats.<ref>in Marcial Solana, ''El tradicionalismo político español y la ciencia hispana'', Madrid 1951, Vázquez de Mella is mentioned 68 times, Gil Robles 46 times, Ramón Nocedal 25 times, Menendez Pelayo 25 times and Aparisi Guijarro 23 times, referred after Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 370</ref> One student names Gil "most systematic doctrinaire of Traditionalism of the early 20th century" and considers de Mella his follower.<ref>"doctrinario más sistemático del tradicionalismo a comienzos del siglo XX" - González Cuevas 2008, p. 1163. For key differences between Gil Robles and Vázquez de Mella see Bartyzel 2015, p. 140 and García Canales 2015, p. 26</ref> In the Spanish public discourse Gil remains largely unknown<ref>the popular Madrid daily ''ABC'' mentioned Enrique Gil Robles only 3 times during 20 years between 1996 and 2016, compare [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/avanzada.stm here]</ref> and hence, unlike some other Traditionalist thinkers, does not generate controversy.<ref>most controversial case having been [[Víctor Pradera Larumbe|Víctor Pradera]]</ref> In the international realm popular works of mostly foreign historians portrayed him as sort of proto-fascist.<ref>especially Paul Preston; "sin duda, el historiador británico no ha leído ni a Enrique Gil Robles, ni a Juan Vázquez de Mella, ni a Víctor Pradera; y tiende, con su habitual ignorancia, a presentar el carlismo como una especie de remedo del fascismo, sin tener en cuenta el antiestatismo y antitotalitarismo característicos del tradicionalismo carlista", Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''En torno a la obra del hispanista Paul Preston'', [in:] ''Catoblepas'' 91 (2009), available [http://www.nodulo.org/ec/2009/n091p01.htm here]</ref> Also specialized Spanish scholars, when discussing his general contribution to right-wing thought, despite Gil’s vehement hostility towards omnipotent state admit that "generic organicist ideas that emerged in a general movement of reflux of individualism, put in front of the social question, eventually facilitated the arrival in the twenties to authoritarian or totalitarian corporatist solutions."<ref>García Canales 2015, p. 22</ref>

'''Ethics of bioprinting''' is a sub-field of [[ethics]] concerning [[bioprinting]]. Some of the ethical issues surrounding bioprinting include equal access to treatment, clinical safety complications, and the enhancement of human body (Dodds 2015).<ref name="SD_2015">Dodds, S. (2015, February 11). [http://www.abc.net.au/science/articles/2015/02/11/4161675.htm 3D printing raises ethical issues in medicine]. Retrieved from ABC Medicine.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/news/10604035/3D-printing-human-tissue-and-organs-to-spark-ethics-debate.html |title=3D printing human tissue and organs to 'spark ethics debate' |author=Rhiannon Williams |date=29 January 2014 |newspaper=The Telegraph }}</ref>
3D printing was invented by Charles Hull in the mid 1980s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.3dhubs.com/what-is-3d-printing|title=What is 3D Printing? The definitive guide|website=3D Hubs|language=en|access-date=2018-05-06}}</ref> 3D printing is a process in additive manufacturing which uses a digital design to produce a physical copy. This process is carried out by a specific printer, which uses several layers in order to complete the design. However, bioprinting uses the ways of 3D printing to create things such as organs, tissues, cells, blood vessels, prosthetics and a broad range of other things that can be used in the medical field.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.innovateus.net/health/what-bioprinting|title=What is Bioprinting?|website=www.innovateus.net|language=en|access-date=2018-05-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.explainingthefuture.com/bioprinting.html|title=ExplainingTheFuture.com : Bioprinting|website=www.explainingthefuture.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-06}}</ref> The "Pioneers" of bioprinting include, Organovo, Tissue Engineering and Regenerative medicine Lab at Columbia University, Makoto Nakamura, to name a few. These pioneers have all helped to shape bioprinting into what it is. The ethics of bioprinting have been a topic of discussion as long as bioprinting has been popular. Ethics are moral principles that govern production, behavior, etc.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.scu.edu/ethics/ethics-resources/ethical-decision-making/what-is-ethics/|title=What is Ethics? - Markkula Center for Applied Ethics|last=University|first=Santa Clara|website=www.scu.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-05-06}}</ref>
== Equal access to treatment ==
Bioprinting focuses on the individual care rather than developing a universal treatment plan for all patients. [[Personalized medicine]] is expensive and increases the disparity between the rich and poor. Since 3D printing is an individual treatment, the general public assumes that it may prevent people with financial issues from receiving care. However, bioprinting improves [[universal health care|universal access]] to healthcare because it will eventually "bring down the time and cost" of treatment.<ref name="SD_2015"/> For example, [[prosthetic limb]]s and [[orthopedic surgery]] can be done in an efficient and inexpensive manner. People would not have to wait months for their prosthetics, which will ultimately decrease the medical expense. The bioprinter may be used to manufacture bone replacements and produce customized prosthetic limbs quickly. Also the printing of human organs, and tissues, are available with decreased time, only taking a few weeks to produce instead of a regular transplant. Currently in the United states the Transplant list is 115,000 people are awaiting a transplant, which can take nearly two years to obtain, while nearly 2 million people have lost a limb.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.amputee-coalition.org/limb-loss-resource-center/resources-filtered/resources-by-topic/limb-loss-statistics/limb-loss-statistics/|title=Limb Loss Statistics - Amputee Coalition|work=Amputee Coalition|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americantransplantfoundation.org/about-transplant/facts-and-myths/|title=Facts and Myths – American Transplant Foundation|website=www.americantransplantfoundation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-06}}</ref> Those who were previously excluded from these medical advancements will now have access to them.
== Safety ==
Any new treatment involving 3D printers is risky and patients must be well informed of the health implications. Doctors hope in the future to print organs in order to replace dysfunctional bio-structures. Similar to organ donations, the cells must match genetically otherwise the recipient’s body will reject the organ. The patient would have an autoimmune response and destroy the donated tissue. The individual’s stem cells must be used to manufacture the organ for the specific patient. In order to advance this technology the medical field must find a way to test and standardize organ production.
== Human enhancement ==
Bioprinting may be used to increase human performance, strength, speed, or endurance. For instance, bioprinting may be used to manufacture enhanced bones and replace regular human bones that are stronger and more flexible. The 3d printer could also be used to increase muscle performance by making muscles more "resilient and less likely to become fatigued".<ref name="SD_2015"/> [[Lung capacity]] could also be improved by replacing it with an artificial lung that can increase oxygen efficiency in the blood. Human enhancement would have a dangerous but incredible impact on society; bioprinting could create a culture without disease or imperfection.
== Legality and policies == Brioprinted items must require regulation. In the United States this is the job of FDA. The FDA must make sure that printed organs are handled a bit differently then human organs because while Biopriting is a growing field, still little is known about it and what it does to the human body.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pennlawreview.com/print/166-U-Pa-L-Rev-515.pdf|title=FDA Regulation of 3D Printed Organs and Associated Ethical Challenges|last=Kelly|first=Elizabeth|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In bioprinting we face tradeoffs between restricted use and open use. Restricted use will allow bioprinting to only be done by trained professionals, where as, open use is more of a free for all. There are also trade offs between if it is ethical to mass produce organs or if it could make issues in transplant cases worse. The legality behind bioprinting is a means in which selling organs on the black market is deemed a problem but is the production and selling of bioprinted items also fall under that law.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eds-a-ebscohost-com.unh-proxy01.newhaven.edu/eds/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=16&sid=53688a72-1ced-48cd-bc95-6ac15b8b0d7a@sessionmgr4006|title=Marvin K. Peterson Library at UNH|last=MacDougall|first=Alan|website=eds-a-ebscohost-com.unh-proxy01.newhaven.edu|access-date=2018-05-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Vermeulen|first=Niki|last2=Haddow|first2=Gill|last3=Seymour|first3=Tirion|last4=Faulkner-Jones|first4=Alan|last5=Shu|first5=Wenmiao|date=2017-03-20|title=3D bioprint me: a socioethical view of bioprinting human organs and tissues|url=http://jme.bmj.com/content/early/2017/03/20/medethics-2015-103347|journal=Journal of Medical Ethics|language=en|pages=medethics–2015–103347|doi=10.1136/medethics-2015-103347|issn=0306-6800|pmid=28320774}}</ref>

'''Frode Alfson Bjørdal''' (born 1960) is professor emeritus in philosophy at the [[University of Oslo]], Norway, and professor colaborador at ''Programa de pós-graduação em filosofia'' at the [[Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte]] in Natal, Brazil.
== Education == Bjørdal did his undergraduate studies in philosophy, logic and economics at the University of Bergen, Norway, and was a DAAD-Stipendiat at the Johan Wolfgang Goethe Universität in Frankfurt am Main, Germany, in 1985/86. He continued his studies in philosophy at [[University of California, Santa Barbara]], USA, from 1988 to 1992, and got this PhD from there in 1993.
== Career == From 1992 to 1994 Bjørdal was a university lecturer at the University of Trondheim (now the [[Norwegian University of Science and Technology]]), from 1994 to 1996 an associate professor at the [[University of Tromsø]] and from 1996 to 2005 an associate professor at the University of Oslo. As from 2005 he is a full professor at the University of Oslo, and as from 2013 he is professor emeritus there. As from 2013 he is also a professor colaborador at the Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte.
== Scientific interests == Bjørdal has mainly been preoccupied with developing an alternative set theory £ (libra) which serves as a foundation for mathematics and deals with the set theoretical and semantical paradoxes in a novel manner. He is also preoccupied with topics in the philosophy of religion, and as a logician he has wide interests in other central areas in philosophy such as ethics, metaphysics and epistemology.
== Selected bibliography == * Considerations Contra Cantorianism, in ''The Logica Yearbook 2010,'' pp. 43–52, College Publications 2011. * [http://apcz.umk.pl/czasopisma/index.php/LLP/article/view/LLP.2012.016 Librationist Closures of the Paradoxes], in Logic and Logical Philosophy Vol. 21, No. 4 (2012), 323-361. * The Evaluation Semantics – A Short Introduction, in ''The Logica Yearbook 2011,'' pp. 31–36, College Publications 2012 * Cubes and Hypercubes of Opposition, with Ethical Ruminations on Inviolability, in ''Logica Universalis'' Volume 10, Issue 2–3 (2016), pp 373–376. * [https://arxiv.org/abs/1407.3877 Elements of Librationism] at arXiv:1407.3877. * [http://apcz.umk.pl/czasopisma/index.php/LLP/article/view/LLP.2017.027 All Properties are Divine or God Exists – The Sacred Thesis and its Ontological Argument], first online in Logic and Logical Philosophy 2017.
== External links == * [http://www.hf.uio.no/ifikk/personer/vit/filosofi/emeriti/fbjordal/index.html Home page at the University of Oslo] * [https://www.cristin.no/as/WebObjects/cristin.woa/wa/fres?sort=ar&la=en&action=sok&pnr=24453 Publications in the Norwegian research database Cristin]

'''Ilm-e-Khshnoom'''{{Pronunciation-needed}}<!-- as IPA --> ('science of ecstasy', or 'science of bliss') is a school of [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrian]] philosophy, practiced by a very small minority of the Indian Zoroastrians ([[Parsi people|Parsis]]/[[Irani (India)|Iranis]]), based on a mystic and esoteric, rather than literal, interpretation of religious texts.
==Principal belief== At the core of the philosophy is the belief that faith facilitates a connection to a consciousness that transcends normal experience or critical analysis, and that the prayers of the [[Avesta]], which are to a degree metrical, are a means to achieve that consciousness.
==The ''Saheb-e-Dilan''== In 1875, an eighteen-year-old Parsi named Behramshah Nowroji Shroff left [[Surat]] (Gujarat, [[India]]) for [[Peshawar]] (now in [[Pakistan]]) in search of employment. According to followers of the mystic philosophy, on Shroff's way there, he met a caravan led by members of the ''Saheb-e-Dilan'' ("Masters of the Heart"), who persuaded him to accompany them to their home in the mountains. The ''Saheb-e-Dilan'', according to Shroff, were a group of about 2000 individuals led by 72 Mahgav ([[Magi]]) priests, called the ''Abed Saheb-e-Dilan'', who lived in isolation in the recesses of [[Caucasus Mountains]] (alternatively, in the [[Alborz]] range, around [[Mount Damavand]]). Having accompanied the caravan, say his followers, Behramshah Shroff lived with the ''Saheb-e-Dilan'' for three years, and so obtained an intimate knowledge of their religious practices and traditions which followed a mystic aspect of the teachings of [[Zoroaster|Zarathustra (Zoroaster)]].
Upon his return to India, Shroff gathered a following from among the [[Parsi people|Parsi]] community, who in due course began calling themselves 'Khshnoomists' after 'Khshnoom', or spiritual ecstasy, that they believed were embodied in their prayers and ceremonies.
==20th Century development== Around 1909, Behramshah Nowroji Shroff met the Parsi priest and Zoroastrian scholar Phiroze Masani, who, influenced by the temperance movement of the United States, had established ''The Parsi Vegetarian & Temperance Society'' in Bombay two years earlier. The philosophy of the ''Ilm-e-Kshnoom'' had a deep influence on Masani, who in turn began publishing Shroff's teachings in ''Frashogard'' ('renewal'), the society's Gujarati quarterly.
In 1917, the society, together with its sister organization, the ''Zoroastrian Radih Society'', bought a large tract of land in Bombay with the intention of establishing a [[Fire temple|Fire Temple]] and a Zoroastrian residential complex there. The foundations were laid in 1923 by Behramshah Shroff himself, but it was not until 2001 that the Fire-Temple, now known as the "Behramshah Nowroji Shroff Daremeher", could be consecrated. The residential complex, now known as "Behram Baug", grew up around it.
Behramshah Nowroji Shroff died in 1927.
==Publications== Phiroze Masani continued to publish the ''Frashogard'' until his death in 1943. In 1947, Jehangir Chiniwalla, the younger brother of Framroze Chiniwalla, one of the more prolific authors of articles in the ''Frashogard'', began publishing the weekly newspaper "Parsi Avaz".
The ''Parsi Avaz'', which remained in print for 27 years, was followed by the ''Dini Avaz'' in Bombay in 1976, and the "Mazdayasni Connection" in the United States in 1983. The ''Parsi Pukar'', founded in [[Bombay]] in 1995, is today the primary publication of followers of the ''Ilm-e-Kshnoom''.
==Further reading== * [https://www.wisdomlib.org/zoroastrianism/book/a-manual-of-khshnoom/index.html "A Manual of Khshnoom" - Readable HTML format with various research functions] * [http://www.frashogard.com/ frashogard.com: The Journal of Ilm-e-Khshnoom] <!-- todo: check if this page is frequently updated. April 2006 shows 1511 page hits --> * [http://www.zarathushtra.org/E-books/AManualofKshnoom.pdf A Manual of Khshnoom]

{{Infobox organization | name = Indigenous Peoples Council on Biocolonialism | logo = IPCB-logo.jpg | logo_size = 120px | type = [[Non-governmental organization]] | founded_date = 1999 | location = [[Nixon, Nevada]], [[United States]] | key_people = | area_served = [[World]]wide | focus = [[Indigenous rights]] | method = | revenue = | num_members = | homepage = [http://www.ipcb.org/ ipcb.org/] }} The '''Indigenous Peoples Council on Biocolonialism''' ('''IPCB''') is a [[non-profit organization]] based in [[Nixon, Nevada|Nixon]], [[Nevada]] for the purpose of [[political activism]] against the emergent field of [[population genetics]] for [[human migration]] research. The term "biocolonialism" is a [[neologism]] —a [[portmanteau]] of "[[biology|bio-]]" and "[[colonialism]]" —used by the IPCB to pejoratively characterise population genetics research as part of invasive and destructive [[cultural assimilation|assimilation]] against [[indigenous peoples]].
The group claims to advocate for the interests of indigenous peoples, to assist "in the protection of their genetic resources, indigenous knowledge, cultural and human rights from the negative effects of [[biotechnology]]."<ref>[http://www.ipcb.org/about_us/our_mission.html IPCB Website - Our mission]</ref> In particular, the IPCB's protests were based on a rejection of participating in scientific research that would negate or otherwise contradict traditional [[Native American mythology|Native American accounts and narratives]] about their [[creation myth|ancestral origins]], and lend support to other alternate views.
IPCB was a signatory of the [[Indigenous Peoples' Seattle Declaration]] in 1999.<ref>http://www.ldb.org/indi99.htm</ref>
==History==
The IPCB was founded in 1999 by the current Executive Director Debra Harry, following her growing concerns over a perceived impact of genetic colonialism on the lives of indigenous peoples.<ref>{{cite book |title=Environmental Justice and Environmentalism: The Social Justice Challenge to the Environmental Movement |last=Sandler |first=Ronald |publisher=The MIT Press |year=2007 |isbn=0-262-69340-2}}</ref> The organization objects to genetic variation research on isolated populations, as well as its prospective commercial exploration; claiming it as a global threat, not only to the self-determination of all indigenous peoples, but also to the non-indigenous world and to the earth itself.
In 2005 and 2006, the group protested against the [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]]'s [[Genographic Project]] (cf. [[Genographic Project#Criticism|criticism]]).
==See also== * [[Convention on Biological Diversity]] * [[George Annas]], a director of IPCB * [[Jonathan Marks (anthropologist)|Jonathan Marks]], a director of IPCB * [[Stuart Newman]], a director of IPCB
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Chris Richards, ''Interview with Debra Harry and the Indigenous Peoples Council on Biocolonialism'', New Internationalist, December 2005 accessed at [http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0JQP/is_385/ai_n15970745] August 4, 2006 * Statements by organizations representing indigenous and local communities, on Convention on Biological Diversity website, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/20060522170645/http://www.biodiv.org/programmes/socio-eco/traditional/instruments.aspx?grp=STA] August 4, 2006
==External links== * [http://www.ipcb.org/ IPCB] - Official website
